item.title: Lavish Lives of Kremlin's Ultra-Rich Daughters...
item.description:
news.yahoo.com
Photo Illustration by The Daily Beast/Vyacheslav Prokofyev/GettyMOSCOWâ€”A new generation of elite Russian women with high-standing fathersâ€”including ministers, members of parliament or top bureaucrats in the Kremlinâ€”manage multimillion-dollar businesses, enjoy luxurious lifestyles, and pose in glitzy photos for high-fashion magazines and social media accounts with vast followings.Privileges, senior positions, low-rate bank credits, and fat stakes in companies fall on the Kremlinâ€™s daughters as manna from heaven. They are growing rich and successful, bringing welcomed womenâ€™s faces to top jobsâ€”and raising thorny questions along the way.Women donâ€™t often climb to the top of Russiaâ€™s male-dominated business or political pyramids. Twice as many men than women start their own companies. But connections, especially close family members in power, have been skyrocketing Russian women to careers at banks and business corporations.Moscow Super-Rich Kickstart Post-COVID Party Season With a Transparent Nunsâ€™ Habit and ClawsLong believed to be daughters of President Vladimir Putin, 34-year-old Yekaterina Tikhonova and 36-year-old Maria Vorontsovaâ€”two of the most mysterious ladies in Russiaâ€™s business and science sectorsâ€”manage projects with billion-dollar budgets.A former acrobatic dancer, Tikhonova was only 28 when she took over a $1.5 billion project developing Science and Technology Park at Moscow State University. Vorontsova, an endocrinologist often referred to in Russian media as â€œthe first daughter,â€ reportedly oversees a program developing genetic technologies with more than a billion-dollar budget.Last week, the youngest daughter of the Russian defense minister, 30-year-old Ksenia Shoigu, decided to sell her successful IT startup company that made more than $3 million last year. She launched the venture fund, Sistema SmartTech, in 2020. While Kseniaâ€™s father Sergei Shoigu oversees one of the worldâ€™s most powerful militaries, his daughter has led a surprisingly public lifestyle: she organizes sporting events, presents business projects and takes part in one fashion shoot after another. â€œI am a mother of all projects,â€ Shoigu, dressed in a French designer dress, said in one interview.Most of the other Kremlin daughters stray away from independent journalists or public events. â€œThe maximum the daughters are allowed to do is attend an annual ball organized by Tatler magazine,â€ Anna Mongait, a socialite and television presenter, told The Daily Beast.Every year, the Russian elite present their daughtersâ€”clad in furs, crazy-expensive ball dresses, and sometimes with fans in handâ€”at the annual Tatler ball. Yelizoveta Peskova, the 17-year-old blond daughter of the Kremlinâ€™s spokesman, Dmitry Peskov, debuted at the annual ball in 2015. Twenty-three year old Leonela Manturova, daughter of the minister of industry and trade, Denis Manturov, debuted in 2018. A year later, the granddaughter of a former prime minister, Anastasia Chernomyrdina, made her big splash.Moscowâ€™s been gossiping about the daughter of Russiaâ€™s deputy prime minister, Maria Shuvalova, since 2018, when the richest ballerina of Bolshoi Theater launched her career and won solo parts at the countryâ€™s top theater. Russian ballerinas view Bolshoi as a cathedral of artsâ€”to appear on the Bolshoiâ€™s stage is a great honor. Still, it is hard to make a great fortune off ballet: the typical salaries at the Bolshoi vary between $500 and $2,500 a month. Vladimir Putin at the State Academic Bolshoi Theatre in Moscow. ALEXEI DRUZHININ/AFP via Getty Images Not only has Mariaâ€™s father been close to President Putin for two decades, he also played a role in overseeing Russiaâ€™s multi-billion dollar sovereign wealth fund. The Kremlinâ€™s ballerina owns stakes in a London-based company, Regional Property Developments Limited, as well as elite property in Russia. She travels around the world and has posed on a yacht in Dubai for her Instagram account. According to an investigative report by Baza news site, the 18-year-old ballerina made more than $20 million in 2018. View this post on Instagram A post shared by ğ™¼ğšŠğš›ğš¢ ğš‚ğš‘ğšğšŸ.ğŸˆâ€â¬› (@mary.marss) A decade ago, Shuvalovaâ€™s father was known as one of the reforming voices in the Kremlinâ€™s liberal wing of politicians, supporting investigations into corruption in state projects. But his latest statements are more vague. â€œOf course, we would like to have it very much,â€ Shuvalov recently said about democracy. â€œBut it does not happen in one day. It will take years of hard work.â€ Needless to say, Russians have never heard Shuvalovâ€™s daughter ever articulate her ideas about corruption, environmental issues, or human rights.Although Russian eliteâ€™s daughters are surely proud of their influential parents, they are not encouraged to have a voice in politics. Their time is more often spent making money on Instagram advertisements, rather than on chronicling political rallies or human rights abuse, like Alexandra Pelosi, the daughter of the U.S. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi. Almost none of them write political columns, like Meghan McCain, or bestselling books on acute issues, like Katherine Schwarzenegger, daughter of the former governor of California, Arnold Schwarzenegger.â€œMost of these young women in their twenties and thirties would have never got their managing positions and big stakes in business companies, if not for their fathersâ€™ powerful connections,â€ a former Member of Parliament, Gennady Gudkov, told The Daily Beast on Wednesday. â€œTo stay wealthy and successful, they keep their mouths shut: every daughter understands perfectly well that once she begins to comment on corruption or human rights her dad will be in the epicenter of a ruinous scandal.â€There are exceptions. The socialite Ksenia Sobchak, known as â€œPutinâ€™s goddaughter,â€ has built a business and entertainment empire over years of show-business toiling, though her famous name surely pushed her foot through the door. She appears on covers of leading fashion magazines, posed naked while pregnant for Tatler, and leverages her giant social media following for profits. The television diva also attends fashion shows all over the world, and makes millions of dollars on television projects and her restaurant business. View this post on Instagram A post shared by ĞšÑĞµĞ½Ğ¸Ñ Ğ¡Ğ¾Ğ±Ñ‡Ğ°Ğº (@xenia_sobchak) To everybodyâ€™s surprise, the socialite, whose fatherâ€”the mayor of St. Petersburgâ€”was once Putinâ€™s boss, joined Russiaâ€™s opposition movement in 2011, in spite of police detentions and cancelled contracts on state television.She recorded multiple videos addressed to Putin, who she has known since her early childhood, confronting the countryâ€™s leader about the outrageous corruption and political persecutions carried out by Kremlin law enforcement. â€œI do have iron balls,â€ Sobchak told The Daily Beast in 2012.But the time of Sobchakâ€™s resistance against the Kremlin is long gone. Political analysts say Sobchakâ€™s decision to take part in the 2018 presidential elections was the Kremlinâ€™s idea to distract public attention away from more genuine opposition candidates. Only 1.6 percent of Russians voted for Sobchak. Since then, her critical voice has gone silent, and her Instagram is once again buzzing with selfies at the beach.Putinâ€™s Alleged Daughter Joins the Chaos as Russia Goes Wild on ClubhouseTo be fair, no small share of Russian men have climbed Moscowâ€™s career ladders in the footsteps of their powerful fathers. Minister of Agriculture Dmitry Patrushev is the son of Security Council Secretary Nikolai Patrushev. Earlier this year, the son of Putinâ€™s university friend Victor Khmarin was appointed general director of Russiaâ€™s major hydroelectric company, RusHydro.One of the youngest Kremlin daughters, Yelizoveta Peskova, has said she considers herself a feminist but not in a confrontational mold. She said, graphically, that she disliked â€œthe manly women who call for pissing on the face of male opinion.â€On April 25, a few days after police came to Alexei Navalnyâ€™s Anti-Corruption Foundation in Moscow and shut down his teamâ€™s operation, Peskovaâ€™s company opened a new pizzeria, Da Giovanni, in the same building at Omega Plaza business center.â€œNone of the Kremlinâ€™s daughters call for womenâ€™s empowerment, address global warming, the plight of immigrants or the horrible problem with domestic violence,â€ Kagershin Sagiyeva, an observer on independent Rain TV, told The Daily Beast. â€œWe wonâ€™t hear their voices unless the patterns of patriarchy and the power of men over women are really addressed.â€Read more at The Daily Beast.Get our top stories in your inbox every day.
